person_819.name: Xenophanes
person_819.description: Greek philosopher, theologian, poet, and critic of Homer from Ionia who travelled throughout the Greek-speaking world in early Classical Antiquity. As a poet, Xenophanes was known for his critical style, writing poems that are considered among the first satires.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_801.name: Herodotus
person_801.description: Greek historian and geographer who wrote a detailed account of the Greco-Persian Wars - one the earliest existing historical texts.

person_508.name: Lucretius
person_508.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

person_510.name: Strabo
person_510.description: Greek geographer, philosopher, and historian who lived in Asia Minor during the transitional period of the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire.

person_185.name: Pliny
person_185.description: The Elder. Roman army officer and author who wrote an encyclopedic Natural History. Died in the aftermath of the eruption of Vesuvius.

person_061.name: AlbertusMagnus
person_061.description: Wrote on natural philossophy. alchemy and much else besides. Bishop of Regensburg (Ratisbon), 1260-1262 and from 1931 a Doctor of the Church.

person_1084.name: RobertPlot
person_1084.description: Robert Plot was an English naturalist and antiquarian who was the first professor of chemistry at the University of Oxford and the first keeper of the Ashmolean Museum.

person_701.name: ThomasBrowne
person_701.description: Seventeenth-century writer, especially on the natural world.

person_1087.name: EdwardLhuyd
person_1087.description: Geologist, naturalist and botanist, assistant to Robert Plot at the Ashmolean Museum, Fellow of the Royal Society

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_1088.name: JohnRay
person_1088.description: A Christian English naturalist widely regarded as one of the earliest of the English parson-naturalists. Until 1670, he wrote his name as John Wray. FRS.

person_039.name: JohnWoodward
person_039.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_300.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
person_300.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

person_033.name: Torbern OlafBergman
person_033.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

person_244.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
person_244.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

person_276.name: UlisseAldrovandi
person_276.description: Italian naturalist and father of natural history according to Buffon and Linneaus.

person_149.name: CharlesHatchett
person_149.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

person_302.name: Johann JakobScheuchzer
person_302.description: Swiss geologist and palaeontologist within a Biblical context. He was a diluvialist and believed that rock strata and fossils were deposited during the Great Flood. His account of the supposed remains of a human who witnessed the flood (Homo Diluvii Testis) was published in Latin in 1726. ForMemRSL.

person_596.name: Uno vonTroil
person_596.description: Swedish traveller and the archbishop of Uppsala. He travelled to Iceland with Joseph Banks.

person_1089.name: SarahMurray Aust
person_1089.description: An English travel writer, best known for her Companion and Useful Guide to the Beauties of Scotland (1799). She published under the name The Hon. Mrs. Murray, of Kensington, though after her second marriage she was also known as Sarah Aust.

person_287.name: ThomasWebster
person_287.description: Assisted lecturers at the RI, including making transparencies use in Davy's courses of lectures on geology.

place_569.name: Sicily
place_569.description: Sicily is the largest and most populous island in the Mediterranean Sea and one of the twenty regions of Italy.

place_1312.name: Cologne
place_1312.description: city spanning the Rhine River in western Germany

place_121.name: England
place_121.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

place_1321.name: Ingleborough
place_1321.description: the second-highest mountain in the Yorkshire Dales, England.

place_287.name: Yorkshire
place_287.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_1322.name: Mont Granier
place_1322.description: a limestone mountain located between the départements of Savoie and Isère in France.

place_226.name: Geneva
place_226.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

place_1323.name: Minehead
place_1323.description: a coastal town and civil parish in Somerset, England

place_991.name: Freiberg
place_991.description: A university and former mining town in Saxony, Germany

place_1398.name: Pembrokeshire
place_1398.description: A county in the south-west of Wales.

place_375.name: Bath, Somerset
place_375.description: Bath is a city in the county of Somerset, England, known for and named after its Roman-built baths.

place_1401.name: Linlithgow
place_1401.description: A town in West Lothian, Scotland, lying approximately twenty miles west of Edinburgh. Davy possibly refers to it when he mentions 'Lithgow' in his geological discussion on basalt: The Edinburgh Review notes that '...there is a thin seam of coal below a bed of beautiful columnar basaltes, at Hillhouse lime-quarry, a mile south of Linlithgow' (Vol IX, 1807, p. 69).

place_1193.name: Staffa
place_1193.description: an island of the Inner Hebrides in Argyll and Bute, Scotland.

place_1035.name: Fingal's Cave
place_1035.description: a sea cave on the uninhabited island of Staffa, in the Inner Hebrides of Scotland, known for its natural acoustics.

place_126.name: Giant's Causeway
place_126.description: The Giant's Causeway is an extensive area of columnar basalt in County Antrim, Northern Ireland, formed by an ancient volcanic fissure eruption.

place_301.name: County Antrim
place_301.description: A county in north-eastern Northern Ireland.

place_1399.name: Isle of Eigg
place_1399.description: Second largest of the Small Isles in the Scottish Inner Hebrides. The Sgurr is a pitchstone rock formation on the island, formed 58 million years ago as the result of a pyroclastic volcanic flow from neighbouring Skye; these rocks are mentioned by Davy in his geology lectures,

place_085.name: Derbyshire
place_085.description: Derbyshire is a county in the East Midlands and includes part of the Peak District.

place_1029.name: Durham, England
place_1029.description: a city in northeast England, south of Newcastle upon Tyne.

place_079.name: Cumberland
place_079.description: Cumberland is a historic county in the far north-west of England.

place_1359.name: Northumberland
place_1359.description: County in the North East of England. It borders Scotland to the north and the county of Cumbria to the west.

place_306.name: Alston Moor
place_306.description: A civil parish in Cumbria, England, based around the small town of Alston.

place_1363.name: River Tees
place_1363.description: The River Tees, in England, rises on the eastern slope of Cross Fell in the North Pennines and flows eastwards for 85 miles to reach the North Sea in the North East of England.
